hypotheses.title: Suspicious Data Transfer to Unusual External Hosts
hypotheses.action: Identify data transfers > 10MB to uncommon external IPs in 1h window using NetFlow logs.

sigma.yaml:
title: Unusual Data Transfer to External Hosts
logsource:
  category: network
  product: netflow
  service: network
detection:
    selection:
      FlowBytes: '>10485760'
    condition: selection

splunk.spl: index=netflow FlowBytes>10485760 | stats count by dest_ip | where count < 3

hypotheses.findings_example: Data transfer of 15MB to external IP 203.0.113.5 with FlowBytes > 10485760.

methodologies_enriched.name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
methodologies_enriched.description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network locat

hypotheses.title: Unusual Access of Sensitive Files
hypotheses.action: Detect multiple accesses to sensitive files from a single user in 10m using Sysmon Event ID 11.

sigma.yaml:
title: Multiple Access to Sensitive Files
logsource:
  product: windows
  service: sysmon
detection:
    selection:
      EventID: 11
      TargetFilename|contains: '\confidential\'
    condition: selection | count(5)

splunk.spl: index=sysmon EventID=11 TargetFilename="*\\confidential\\*" | stats count by user | where count >= 5

hypotheses.findings_example: User 'jdoe' accessed 7 files in \confidential\ directory in 10 minutes.

methodologies_enriched.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
methodologies_enriched.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel. Cloud storage services allow for the storage, edit, and retrieval of data from a

hypotheses.title: Credential Dumping Followed by Network Transfer
hypotheses.action: Detect lsass.exe memory dump followed by network transfer in 5m using Sysmon and NetFlow logs.

sigma.yaml:
title: Lsass Dump Followed by Network Transfer
logsource:
  product: windows
  service: sysmon
detection:
    selection1:
      EventID: 10
      TargetObject: '*\lsass.exe'
    selection2:
      EventID: 3
      Image: '*\powershell.exe'
    condition: selection1 and selection2

splunk.spl: index=sysmon (EventID=10 TargetObject="*\lsass.exe") OR (EventID=3 Image="*\powershell.exe") | transaction maxspan=5m | search eventcount=2

hypotheses.findings_example: Process lsass.exe dumped followed by PowerShell network activity within 5 minutes.
